node.contents: No. You cannot access arbitrary memory in Java. But, you can share memory between two JVMs. Use JNI and ipcs. Or sockets over loopback.

node.contents: For example you can write a piece of C++ code that can read an arbitrary memory location and call that via JNI. The same is true in reverse to write to a memory address.

node.contents: Note of caution: I do not recommend doing this. There are almost certainly better ways to do what you want to do.

node.contents: Solution 1:

astNode.text: Solution 1:

node.contents: The best solution in my opinion is to use memory mapped files. This allows you to share a region of memory between any number of process, including other non java programs. You can't place java objects into a memory mapped file, unless you serialize them. The following example shows that you can communicate between two different process, but you would need to make it much more sophisticated to allow better communication between the processes. I suggest you look at Java's NIO package, specifically the classes and methods used in the below examples.

astNode.text: The best solution in my opinion is to use memory mapped files. This allows you to share a region of memory between any number of process, including other non java programs. You can't place java objects into a memory mapped file, unless you serialize them. The following example shows that you can communicate between two different process, but you would need to make it much more sophisticated to allow better communication between the processes. I suggest you look at Java's NIO package, specifically the classes and methods used in the below examples.

node.contents: Server:

astNode.text: Server:

elements.contents: public class Server { public static void main( String[] args ) throws Throwable { File f = new File( FILE_NAME ); FileChannel channel = FileChannel.open( f.toPath(), StandardOpenOption.READ, StandardOpenOption.WRITE, StandardOpenOption.CREATE ); MappedByteBuffer b = channel.map( MapMode.READ_WRITE, 0, 4096 ); CharBuffer charBuf = b.asCharBuffer(); char[] string = "Hello client\0".toCharArray(); charBuf.put( string ); System.out.println( "Waiting for client." ); while( charBuf.get( 0 ) != '\0' ); System.out.println( "Finished waiting." ); } }

units.rawText: public class Server { public static void main( String[] args ) throws Throwable { File f = new File( FILE_NAME ); FileChannel channel = FileChannel.open( f.toPath(), StandardOpenOption.READ, StandardOpenOption.WRITE, StandardOpenOption.CREATE ); MappedByteBuffer b = channel.map( MapMode.READ_WRITE, 0, 4096); CharBuffer charBuf = b.asCharBuffer(); char[] string = "Hello client\0".toCharArray(); charBuf.put( string ); System.out.println( "Waiting for client."); while( charBuf.get( 0 ) != '\0' ); System.out.println( "Finished waiting."); } }

node.contents: Client:

astNode.text: Client:

elements.contents: public class Client { public static void main( String[] args ) throws Throwable { File f = new File( FILE_NAME ); FileChannel channel = FileChannel.open( f.toPath(), StandardOpenOption.READ, StandardOpenOption.WRITE, StandardOpenOption.CREATE ); MappedByteBuffer b = channel.map( MapMode.READ_WRITE, 0, 4096 ); CharBuffer charBuf = b.asCharBuffer(); // Prints 'Hello server' char c; while( ( c = charBuf.get() ) != 0 ) { System.out.print( c ); } System.out.println(); charBuf.put( 0, '\0' ); } }

node.contents: Solution 2:

astNode.text: Solution 2:

node.contents: Another solution is to use Java Sockets to communicate back and forth between processes. This has the added benefit of allowing communication over a network very easily. It could be argued that this is slower than using memory mapped files, but I do not have any benchmarks to back that statement up. I won't post code to implementing this solution, as it can become very complicated to implement a reliable network protocol and is fairly application specific. There are many good networking sites that can be found with quick searches.

astNode.text: Another solution is to use Java Sockets to communicate back and forth between processes. This has the added benefit of allowing communication over a network very easily. It could be argued that this is slower than using memory mapped files, but I do not have any benchmarks to back that statement up. I won't post code to implementing this solution, as it can become very complicated to implement a reliable network protocol and is fairly application specific. There are many good networking sites that can be found with quick searches.

node.contents: Now the above examples are if you want to share memory between two different process. If you just want to read/write to arbitrary memory in the current process, there are some warnings you should know first. This goes against the entire principle of the JVM and you really really should not do this in production code. You violate all safety and can very easily crash the JVM if you are not very careful.

astNode.text: Now the above examples are if you want to share memory between two different process. If you just want to read/write to arbitrary memory in the current process, there are some warnings you should know first. This goes against the entire principle of the JVM and you really really should not do this in production code. You violate all safety and can very easily crash the JVM if you are not very careful.

node.contents: That being said, it is quite fun to experiment with. To read/write to arbitrary memory in the current process you can use the sun.misc.Unsafe class. This is provided on all JVMs that I am aware of and have used. An example on how to use the class can be found here.

astNode.text: That being said, it is quite fun to experiment with. To read/write to arbitrary memory in the current process you can use the sun.misc.Unsafe class. This is provided on all JVMs that I am aware of and have used. An example on how to use the class can be found here.

node.contents: Honestly, you don't want to share the same memory. You should send only the data that you need to the other JVM. That being said, in the case you do need the shared memory, other solutions exist.

astNode.text: Honestly, you don't want to share the same memory. You should send only the data that you need to the other JVM. That being said, in the case you do need the shared memory, other solutions exist.

node.contents: Sending Data Two JVMs do not share the same memory access points, so it is impossible to use a reference from one JVM to use in another. A new reference will simply be create because they don't know about each other.

astNode.text: Sending Data Two JVMs do not share the same memory access points, so it is impossible to use a reference from one JVM to use in another. A new reference will simply be create because they don't know about each other.

node.contents: However, you may ship the data to the other JVM, and back in a variety of ways:

astNode.text: However, you may ship the data to the other JVM, and back in a variety of ways:

node.contents: 1) Using RMI, you can setup a remote server to parse data. I found it a bit of a hassle to set up because it requires security changes and that the data be Serializable. You can find out more at the link.

astNode.text: 1) Using RMI, you can setup a remote server to parse data. I found it a bit of a hassle to set up because it requires security changes and that the data be Serializable. You can find out more at the link.

node.contents: 2) Using a server is the age-old method of sending data to different places. One way to implement this is using a ServerSocket and connecting with a Socket on localhost. Objects still need to be Serializable if you want to use ObjectOutputStream.

astNode.text: 2) Using a server is the age-old method of sending data to different places. One way to implement this is using a ServerSocket and connecting with a Socket on localhost. Objects still need to be Serializable if you want to use ObjectOutputStream.

node.contents: If you want to use Java code, you can take a look at using s.m.Unsafe, using the correct memory addresses, you will be able to retrieve Objects stored by the backing C/C++ arrays in the OS.

node.contents: Otherwise, you can use native methods to access the C/C++ arrays yourself, although I have no clue how this could be implemented.
